rev.diff:
Line 90: Line 90:
*'''November 2 (day 47)''' – Demonstrations continued in [[Occupy Oakland|Oakland]], California, with a citywide general strike taking place in response to the serious injury sustained by a protester on October 25.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/11/02/us/occupy-demonstrators/index.html?iref=allsearch|publisher=CNN|title=Demonstrators gear up for Oakland strike as protests continue|date=November 2, 2011|accessdate=November 2, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-15481506|title=Occupy Oakland seeks strike after Scott Olsen injury|publisher=BBC|date=27 October 2011|accessdate=November 2, 2011}}</ref> Protesters shut down the [[Port of Oakland]], the nation's fifth busiest port.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Occupy-Oakland-Hosts-General-Strike-133081358.html|title=General Strike Shuts Down Port of Oakland|publisher=NBC|date=Nov 2, 2011 |accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref> A man was arrested for sexual assault and rape at the NYC OWS encampment.<ref>http://blogs.wsj.com/metropolis/2011/11/02/man-arrested-in-sex-assaults-at-occupy-wall-street/</ref>
*'''November 2 (day 47)''' – Demonstrations continued in [[Occupy Oakland|Oakland]], California, with a citywide general strike taking place in response to the serious injury sustained by a protester on October 25.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/11/02/us/occupy-demonstrators/index.html?iref=allsearch|publisher=CNN|title=Demonstrators gear up for Oakland strike as protests continue|date=November 2, 2011|accessdate=November 2, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-15481506|title=Occupy Oakland seeks strike after Scott Olsen injury|publisher=BBC|date=27 October 2011|accessdate=November 2, 2011}}</ref> Protesters shut down the [[Port of Oakland]], the nation's fifth busiest port.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Occupy-Oakland-Hosts-General-Strike-133081358.html|title=General Strike Shuts Down Port of Oakland|publisher=NBC|date=Nov 2, 2011 |accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref> A man was arrested for sexual assault and rape at the NYC OWS encampment.<ref>http://blogs.wsj.com/metropolis/2011/11/02/man-arrested-in-sex-assaults-at-occupy-wall-street/</ref>
â
*'''November 3 (day 48)''' – Riot police clashed with [[Occupy Oakland]], firing tear gas and [[flash bang grenades]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2011/11/occupy-oakland-tear-gas-arrests.html|publisher=LA Times|title=Riot police fire projectiles, arrest dozens of Occupy Oakland protester|date=November 3, 2011|accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref> Over a hundred protesters were arrested, and including another Iraq veteran who was seriously injured by police.<ref>[http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8419771 Second veteran injured in 'Occupy Oakland' violence]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/occupy-oakland-protesters-tear-gased-police-101824932.html|title=Occupy Oakland Protesters Tear Gassed by Police|publisher=Yahoo News|date=November 3, 2011|accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref> [[Occupy Seattle]] protesters and police briefly clashed in protests sparked by Chase CEO [[Jamie Dimon]]'s visit to town. Five protesters were arrested for breaking into the bank, and two police officers sustained minor injuries. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/11/occupy-seattle-chase-dimon.html|title=Occupy Seattle swoops in around JPMorgan Chase executive|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=November 3, 2011|accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref>
+
'''November 3 (day 48)''' – Riot police clashed with [[Occupy Oakland]], firing tear gas and [[flash bang grenades]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2011/11/occupy-oakland-tear-gas-arrests.html|publisher=LA Times|title=Riot police fire projectiles, arrest dozens of Occupy Oakland protester|date=November 3, 2011|accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref> Over a hundred protesters were arrested, and including another Iraq veteran who was seriously injured by police.<ref>[http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8419771 Second veteran injured in 'Occupy Oakland' violence]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/occupy-oakland-protesters-tear-gased-police-101824932.html|title=Occupy Oakland Protesters Tear Gassed by Police|publisher=Yahoo News|date=November 3, 2011|accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref> [[Occupy Seattle]] protesters and police briefly clashed in protests sparked by Chase CEO [[Jamie Dimon]]'s visit to town. Five protesters were arrested for breaking into the bank, and two police officers sustained minor injuries. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/nationnow/2011/11/occupy-seattle-chase-dimon.html|title=Occupy Seattle swoops in around JPMorgan Chase executive|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=November 3, 2011|accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
*'''November 5 (day 50)''' – To participate in both [[Guy Fawkes Day]] and [[Bank Transfer Day]], demonstrators protested outside major banks and financial institutions. In the preceding month, over 600,000 people closed their bank accounts and opened accounts with local credit unions. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://inagist.com/OccupyLSX/132973217341120513/|title=600,000 Americans have moved their funds from banks to credit unions in the past month. The revolution is underway.|accessdate=7 November 2011}}</ref>
*'''November 5 (day 50)''' – To participate in both [[Guy Fawkes Day]] and [[Bank Transfer Day]], demonstrators protested outside major banks and financial institutions. In the preceding month, over 600,000 people closed their bank accounts and opened accounts with local credit unions. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://inagist.com/OccupyLSX/132973217341120513/|title=600,000 Americans have moved their funds from banks to credit unions in the past month. The revolution is underway.|accessdate=7 November 2011}}</ref>
Line 96: Line 96:
*'''November 14 (day 59)''' – Occupy Oakland is cleared by police; twenty protestors are arrested. Oakland Mayor Jean Quan cited the eviction as a response to the "tremendous strain" the camp had put the city's resources <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/nov/14/occupy-oakland-police-action-live|title=Occupy Oakland: demonstrators prepare for police action â live updates.|accessdate=14 November 2011}}</ref> . The mayor's legal advisor, Dan Siegel, has resigned from his position in protest of the eviction. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/nov/14/occupy-oakland-police-action-live|title=Occupy Oakland: demonstrators prepare for police action â live updates.|accessdate=14 November 2011}}</ref>
*'''November 14 (day 59)''' – Occupy Oakland is cleared by police; twenty protestors are arrested. Oakland Mayor Jean Quan cited the eviction as a response to the "tremendous strain" the camp had put the city's resources <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/nov/14/occupy-oakland-police-action-live|title=Occupy Oakland: demonstrators prepare for police action â live updates.|accessdate=14 November 2011}}</ref> . The mayor's legal advisor, Dan Siegel, has resigned from his position in protest of the eviction. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/nov/14/occupy-oakland-police-action-live|title=Occupy Oakland: demonstrators prepare for police action â live updates.|accessdate=14 November 2011}}</ref>
â
* '''November 15 (day 60)''' At about 1am, NYPD began to clear Zucotti Park. City Councilman Ydanis Rodriguez is reported to have been arrested during the eviction, along with seventy other protestors<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/16/nyregion/police-begin-clearing-zuccotti-park-of-protesters.html?hp | title=Police Begin Clearing Zuccotti Park of Protester | work=The New York Times | date=November 14, 2011 | accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref>. The official statement released by Mayor Bloomberg's office explained the purpose of the late-night eviction: "This action was taken at this time of day to reduce the risk of confrontation in the park, and to minimize disruption to the surrounding neighborhood...[Mayor Bloomberg] [has] become increasingly concerned â as had the parkâs owner, Brookfield Properties â that the occupation was coming to pose a health and fire safety hazard to the protestors and to the surrounding community" <ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nyc.gov/portal/site/nycgov/menuitem.c0935b9a57bb4ef3daf2f1c701c789a0/index.jsp?pageID=mayor_press_release&catID=1194&doc_name=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nyc.gov%2Fhtml%2Fom%2Fhtml%2F2011b%2Fpr410-11.html&cc=unused1978&rc=1194&ndi=1| title=STATEMENT OF MAYOR MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG ON CLEARING AND RE-OPENING OF ZUCCOTTI PARK | work=Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's Office | date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. Journalists have been barred from entering immediate area of eviction since the raid began, and Mayor Bloomberg cited this as a way "to protect members of the press," and "to prevent a situation from getting worse"<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/15/occupy-wall-street-raid-journalists-arrested_n_1094564.html?ncid=edlinkusaolp00000003| title=Occupy Wall Street 'Media Blackout': Journalists Arrested, Roughed Up, Blocked From Covering Clearing | work=Huffington Post | date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. A CBS press helicopter was not allowed into the airspace above the park, which has been interpreted as an effort to limit media coverage of the event<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/nov/15/occupy-wall-street-police-action-live| title=Occupy Wall Street: police evict protesters - live updates | work=The Guardian| date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. A judge has issued a temporary restraining order in favor of the protestors, requiring Mayor Bloomberg to show cause for eviction <ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/266582-order-re-liberty-park/| title=Order to Show Cause and Temporary Restraining Order | work=Restraining Order | date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. Protesters sporting copies of the court order attempted to reenter the park, but police continued to deny access to square. In response, impromptu general assemblies and meet-ups have started in different locations. Mayor Bloomberg is scheduled to address the court order at 11:30am ET<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/nov/15/occupy-wall-street-police-action-live| title=Occupy Wall Street: police evict protesters - live updates | work=The Guardian| date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. Occupy Wall Street's statement released in response to the eviction cited exercising their right to assemble and the need to create a "civic space" as essential to changing public discourse<ref>{{cite web | url=http://occupywallst.org/article/call-occupy/| title=Call to Occupy | work=Occupy Wall Street Official Website| date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. The Mayor's Office released statement states that the right to freedom of speech has not been violated, and furthermore occupying a space with personal property is not included in First Amendment rights; but the Right to Assemble was not addressed in the statement<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/nov/15/occupy-wall-street-police-action-live| title=Occupy Wall Street: police evict protesters - live updates | work=The Guardian| date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>.
+
====November 15 (day 60)====
  +
* '''Occupy Wall Street''' At about 1am, NYPD began to clear Zucotti Park. City Councilman Ydanis Rodriguez is reported to have been arrested during the eviction, along with seventy other protestors<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/16/nyregion/police-begin-clearing-zuccotti-park-of-protesters.html?hp | title=Police Begin Clearing Zuccotti Park of Protester | work=The New York Times | date=November 14, 2011 | accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref>. The official statement released by Mayor Bloomberg's office explained the purpose of the late-night eviction: "This action was taken at this time of day to reduce the risk of confrontation in the park, and to minimize disruption to the surrounding neighborhood...[Mayor Bloomberg] [has] become increasingly concerned â as had the parkâs owner, Brookfield Properties â that the occupation was coming to pose a health and fire safety hazard to the protestors and to the surrounding community" <ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nyc.gov/portal/site/nycgov/menuitem.c0935b9a57bb4ef3daf2f1c701c789a0/index.jsp?pageID=mayor_press_release&catID=1194&doc_name=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nyc.gov%2Fhtml%2Fom%2Fhtml%2F2011b%2Fpr410-11.html&cc=unused1978&rc=1194&ndi=1| title=STATEMENT OF MAYOR MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG ON CLEARING AND RE-OPENING OF ZUCCOTTI PARK | work=Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's Office | date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. Journalists have been barred from entering immediate area of eviction since the raid began, and Mayor Bloomberg cited this as a way "to protect members of the press," and "to prevent a situation from getting worse"<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/15/occupy-wall-street-raid-journalists-arrested_n_1094564.html?ncid=edlinkusaolp00000003| title=Occupy Wall Street 'Media Blackout': Journalists Arrested, Roughed Up, Blocked From Covering Clearing | work=Huffington Post | date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. A CBS press helicopter was not allowed into the airspace above the park, which has been interpreted as an effort to limit media coverage of the event<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/nov/15/occupy-wall-street-police-action-live| title=Occupy Wall Street: police evict protesters - live updates | work=The Guardian| date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. A judge has issued a temporary restraining order in favor of the protestors, requiring Mayor Bloomberg to show cause for eviction <ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/266582-order-re-liberty-park/| title=Order to Show Cause and Temporary Restraining Order | work=Restraining Order | date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. Protesters sporting copies of the court order attempted to reenter the park, but police continued to deny access to square. In response, impromptu general assemblies and meet-ups have started in different locations. Mayor Bloomberg is scheduled to address the court order at 11:30am ET<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/nov/15/occupy-wall-street-police-action-live| title=Occupy Wall Street: police evict protesters - live updates | work=The Guardian| date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. Occupy Wall Street's statement released in response to the eviction cited exercising their right to assemble and the need to create a "civic space" as essential to changing public discourse<ref>{{cite web | url=http://occupywallst.org/article/call-occupy/| title=Call to Occupy | work=Occupy Wall Street Official Website| date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. The Mayor's Office released statement states that the right to freedom of speech has not been violated, and furthermore occupying a space with personal property is not included in First Amendment rights; but the Right to Assemble was not addressed in the statement<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/nov/15/occupy-wall-street-police-action-live| title=Occupy Wall Street: police evict protesters - live updates | work=The Guardian| date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>.
